Award.AwardTitle: Iterative Methods for Nonlinear Equations and Optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Computation simulation is pervasive in society. Automobiles, aircraft, and mobile phones, for example, need high-quality simulators not only for their design, but also for their operation. In this project the PI will investigate nonlinear solvers, which are core components of many simulators. He will consider classes of problems and solvers for which theory is incomplete or missing. A theoretical understanding of these problems and solvers will lead to improved performance and reliability of the solvers and the simulators which use those solvers. The PI will apply his findings to problems in physics and chemistry basic to the design of materials.

This project addresses some unresolved algorithmic questions in numerical analysis theory. These problems have important applications. The work on optimization and nonlinear solvers with embedded Monte Carlo methods in the objective function or residual is a very new line of research. The work is particularly timely in view of Monte Carlo methods robustness and resiliency in a massively parallel environment. Progress in this topic will lead to better understanding of how to couple existing solvers to Monte Carlo models. The research on Anderson acceleration will explore a class of Jacobian-free solvers which are very important when Jacobians or Jacobian vector products are unavailable. Anderson is already widely used in electronic structure computations which, in turn, are core components in computational chemistry software and the design of materials. While there is wide literature on the use and operation of Anderson acceleration, including cases where it fails to converge, there is very little theory. The object of this part of the project is to develop that theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nonlinear equations and optimization problems are ubiquitous in computational science and engineering. With the support of this project, the PI and his students developed new algorithms for these problems, new ways to understand the properties of the methods, and novel implementations on modern computer architectures. The applications of the work included nuclear engineering, chemistry problems related to solar energy, quantum physics, and finance.
The PI's work on Anderson acceleration is an example of the algorithmic advances that came from the project. Anderson acceleration was invented in 1965 to solve nonlinear equations from quantum physics. It has since become the solver in most quantum chemistry and physics codes. The work in this project included the first convergence analysis of the method and exposed the reasons for some of the limitations that were well-known, but not understood. 
The work on solar energy is an example of the interdisciplinary collaborations in the PI's research. In this project we collaborate with Elena Jakubikova, and chemist at North Carolina State University to design reduced order models of potential energy surfaces. We were among the fist to use sparse grid interpolation for this application. The reduced order models enable the quantum chemistry simulation to model dynamics of molecules after exposure to light. Our work on this has been published not only in the literatures of applied mathematics, electronics, and chemistry.
The project included collaborations with other :wqdisciplines and the students were involved in those collaborations, often publishing in the literature of the other discipline as well as the mathematics literature. The PI's students had internships in national laboratories to develop the collaborations and their skills in interdisciplinary research. One outcome of this training was that the PI's students easily found jobs in academics, industry, and national laboratories.
